page.title: 06TRANSPORT AROUND HEADCORN
page.content: {The A274 Maidstone to Tenterden road runs N-W to S-E across the region and is unusually straight in this Wealden area. Part of the road was built by Napoleonic prisoners during the early part of the 19th. century. This is a through route for heavy lorries and cars and being only 10 miles from the County Town many villagers travel along it for general shopping or to work. Buses provide an hourly service to Maidstone and back (Â£1.10 single adult fare).{Various narrow lanes criss-cross the region. Many of them have their origins in cart tracks or drovers' roads of the early Middle Ages.{The Charing Cross to Ashford {railway line}runs W.to E. along the southern fringe of the village and provides a very fast and frequent commuter service to and from the city. Trains come every 20 minutes sometimes
